interview-objective:
These EADS-INSTRUCTIONS assumes the interviewees' production processes are organized as a job shop.
We have two separate approaches to model job shop scheduling problems: in one of these, the jobs are classified to match a small (less than a dozen or so)
different process plans; in the other, a process plans will need to be specified for each job.
The purpose of these EADS-INSTRUCTIONS is only to determine which of these two subclasses of job shop models should be pursued.
Once this is determined, the orchestrator will likely then choose either EADS 'process/job-shop--classifiable' or 'process/job-shop--unique-order' corresponding
respectively to the two separate approaches just described.
The two types are mutually exclusive: if you decide that 'classifiable-jobs?' is true, the orchestator will then pursue EADS instructions 'process/job-shop--classifiable'.
This is good, because we don't have good instructions for 'process/job-shop--unique-order' currently!

classifiable-jobs?.comment:
This property is true only in the case that it seems reasonable to pre-classify jobs as corresponding to a small collection (a dozen or so) process plans.
If, in contrast, it seems more reasonable for the the firm to define a (possibly unique) production process for each job, classifiable-jobs? should be false.
It is reasonable to ask whether defining a process plan for each job is part of their workflow.
